awd_abstract_narration:
This project will combine molecular and computational biology to study the evolution of diversity in gene expression.  In all organisms, gene expression is controlled, or regulated, by crosstalk between proteins called transcription factors and specific small regions in the DNA that bind the transcription factors (transcription factor binding sites.)  A key to understanding this crosstalk is learning the precise nature of the "regulatory vocabulary" of transcription factor binding sites which potentially varies among organisms.  This project will focus on deciphering the regulatory language in multiple species of the single-celled protozoan Paramecium, a well-established model system in cell biology. The overall project will advance the formal training of undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, while also establishing a set of molecular resources for the international research community. Specific efforts are being made to organize and integrate all genomic and gene-expression results into a web repository that will allow users to readily query data for dozens of Paramecium species to acquire information about status and evolutionary history of all known genes. The scientific and training results from this project will help promote the growth of the field of evolutionary cell biology, thereby broadening our understanding of the diversity of cellular functions across the Tree of Life.

Much of biological diversity owes its origin to gene duplication and modifications in gene regulatory patterns.  The Paramecium system is well-suited to studying the impacts of gene duplication because the evolution of this genus included two complete-genome duplications that led to the establishment of a clade of distantly related but nearly morphologically identical species. This situation is of broad interest because two rounds of genome duplication are also thought to have preceded the emergence and diversification of the major vertebrate lineages. With complete sequences now available for most Paramecium species, and the evolutionary history of each gene known, the next goal is to determine the cellular mechanisms responsible for differential gene expression and the evolutionary mechanisms associated with differential gene survival. Using a set of efficient methods for discovering transcription factor binding sites, this project will elucidate the evolutionary history of the gene-regulation vocabulary over the billion-year history of the genus Paramecium. Comparisons among lineages that did or did not undergo complete-genome duplications will help define the extent to which evolutionary dynamics are altered in the face of massive gene duplication. Paramecium shares some key features with animals, such as harboring a transcriptionally silent germline genome as well as an active somatic nucleus, all within the confines of a single, highly complex cell. Thus, results of these studies in the Paramecium, which is exceptionally easy to manipulate, may shed light on the evolution of regulatory diversity in other organisms that are not as experimentally tractable.

por.por_cntn:
All biological features are ultimately determined by transcription regulation, a complex process that determines when and where individual genes are expressed into messenger RNAs, which are then translated into proteins. This study was focused on elucidating such processes in a model unicellular organism, the ciliate Paramecium, with a goal of moving the system to the forefront of understanding of gene regulation. The work was pursued through a series of high-throughout / whole-genome analyses at the level of DNA, RNA, and protein in multiple species. A large clade of these species, the Paramecium aurelia complex, arose following a complete genome duplication, providing an opportunity to learn the fates of duplicated genes by contrasting observations with those from closely related pre-duplication species.

This study revealed that Paramecium species have the most streamlined genomes so far observed among eukaryotes. Although some species have as many as 40,000 genes (twice the number in humans) and a very large and complex cell, the amount of intergenic DNA (wherein the signals for gene regulation reside) is approximately the same as in bacteria. As a consequence, transcription initiates at nearly the same position as translation initiates, and this has further enhanced the possibilities of identifying the specific motifs (the regulatory vocabulary).

The ancient genome duplication pre-dating the emergence of the 14 aurelia species is notable because, despite speciation more than 400 million years ago, the individual clades of the complex remain morphologically indistinguishable. This level of stasis contrasts strongly with the dramatic diversification of vertebrates that followed another whole-genome duplication at about the same time, demonstrating that rampant gene duplication need not lead to rapid radiations at the morphological level.

Population-genomic analyses of multiple isolates from several species provided the basis for understanding the fates of duplicate genes. Generally, one redundant copy of a pair is eventually lost by degenerative mutations, but gene sequence data reveal that this is a very long process preceded by a slow loss of function of one copy whose fate is determined early and progresses over tens of millions of years. These temporal dynamics were revealed by comparisons of the gene contents of the tree of related species, which enables the identification of points of gene loss. Analysis of the subcellular locations of the proteins produced by surviving gene-pair members reveals numerous cases in which the two copies become subfunctionalized, with the ancestral state of multiple functions being resolved into more specialized descendant copies.

Together, these multiple levels of results provide a compelling evolutionary glimpse into the general aspects of genome evolution in a highly abundant, globally distributed species. They also yield an unprecedented understanding of the dynamics of duplicate-gene evolution, a process that underlies the diversification of almost all major clades of eukaryotes. The genus-wide set of observations at the genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic levels is being made available as an open-access resource for the broader research community.
